s.text: An alarm clock on the washstand is set forever at 5 o'clock as though to mark this epiphany, when the white light struck the woman's breast just so.

The puzzling decision to relegate the painter of sun-drenched tablecloths and rainbow gardens to the underground makes some sense given the direction and drift of the show, the third MoMA retrospective of Bonnard's work since his death just shy of age 80 in 1947.
The marriage, kept secret from Bonnard's family, was the result of a traumatic development in Bonnard's life.

The modern bathroom with its linoleum floor, ceramic tile, and enameled tub--as banal a setting as one could imagine--is transformed in these late masterpieces into a world as rich and exotic as Tutankhamen's tomb (, 1936).
Two of the very late self-portraits have the wartime blackout curtains pulled aside, as though Bonnard is exposed in more ways than one.
The marriage, kept secret from Bonnard's family, was the result of a traumatic development in Bonnard's life.
His face looks bruised and battered, and his small, sunken eyes show the marks where glasses were just removed.
Bonnard's early influences were the work of Paul Gauguin and Japanese prints, both of which confirmed his interest in bold colors and strongly delineated design.
